Using Example Actions: Each proficiency in this toolkit is accompanied by suggested actions – concrete examples of how a student might demonstrate that proficiency. These are guidance, not a mandatory checklist. A student does not need to complete every example action to achieve the proficiency[4]. Instead, the examples illustrate possible approaches. Students and supervisors are encouraged to come up with other equivalent actions relevant to their setting. The focus should remain on the outcome (the proficiency) rather than ticking off tasks. This flexible approach ensures that evidence can be tailored to the individual patient case or placement context, fostering a more holistic and meaningful achievement of competence.

Coaching and Empowerment: Practice Supervisors are encouraged to use a coaching style in day-to-day supervision – asking questions, prompting students to think critically, and gradually increasing their responsibilities. This empowers students to take ownership of their learning and builds confidence. For example, rather than simply showing how to do a task, a supervisor might ask, “How do you think we should approach this patient’s wound dressing?” and guide the student through their reasoning. This approach aligns with the NMC’s emphasis on students learning independence and autonomy in a safe manner[5]. Positive reinforcement and timely, constructive feedback are key to building the student’s competence and professional identity.

Reasonable Adjustments: In line with equality and human rights legislation, reasonable adjustments should be made to support students with disabilities or specific learning needs. This may include adaptive equipment, modified schedules, or alternative ways to demonstrate a skill. The goal is to provide equal opportunity for all students to achieve the proficiencies, without lowering the standard required. Practice educators should work with university disability support and follow local policies to implement adjustments. For example, a student with hearing impairment might use an amplified stethoscope for assessment skills, or a student with dyslexia might be given additional time for written documentation tasks. Such adjustments ensure compliance with the Equality Act and uphold the NMC’s values of fairness and inclusivity, while maintaining patient safety. Open communication between the student, academic staff, and practice supervisors is essential to identify needs early and plan support.

Navigation by Part/Year: The toolkit is divided into Parts 1, 2, and 3, corresponding to the three years of a typical nursing programme. Within each Part, you will find a table listing proficiencies relevant to that stage, along with suggested assessment methods, example actions, and e-learning resources. Users can scroll to the section for the student’s current Part to focus on appropriate proficiencies. It’s expected that Part 1 proficiencies are achieved with guidance, Part 2 with increasing independence, and Part 3 at an entry-level registered nurse standard. However, learning is cumulative: skills from Part 1 continue to be refined in later years. Additionally, some higher-level skills may be introduced in Part 2 but only required by Part 3 – these are marked with an asterisk (*) to indicate they can be

completed in the final year if not achieved earlier. Throughout, the toolkit emphasizes quality of learning over quantity of tasks. Students should use it to identify learning goals, and supervisors/assessors can use it to facilitate learning conversations, plan learning experiences, and verify competence via multiple forms of evidence.

Guidance and Content Introduction

Guidance and Content Introduction

Purpose and Structure: This toolkit serves as a bridge between the NMC’s high-level standards and everyday practice learning. It breaks down broad proficiencies into practice-focused guidance, ensuring students and supervisors understand how to evidence each outcome. The content is structured first by general guidance sections (assessment methods, key NMC statements, supervision guidance, etc.), followed by the detailed proficiency lists for each Part of the programme. This introductory section clarifies expectations for progression across the three Parts and explains how the toolkit incorporates NMC Annexe skills and procedures.

Progression Expectations: Over the three Parts of the nursing programme, students are expected to progress from guided participation to independence and leadership. In Part 1 (Year 1), students participate in care under close guidance, focusing on fundamental skills and building confidence. By Part 2 (Year 2), students take a more active role in care with minimal guidance, performing skills with increased confidence and competence[6]. In Part 3 (Year 3), students should be practising independently with minimal supervision and leading and coordinating care with confidence[7]. This staged progression reflects the increasing complexity of proficiencies: Year 1 emphasizes core skills (communication, basic assessments, personal care, infection control, etc.), Year 2 adds more complex skills (clinical decision-making, managing care for multiple patients, some invasive procedures under supervision), and Year 3 focuses on leadership (team coordination, delegation, autonomous decision-making, and handling complex or rapidly changing situations). The toolkit sections for each Part are designed with this in mind – for instance, Part 3 guidance includes proficiencies related to leadership and

handling complex or rapidly changing situations). The toolkit sections for each Part are designed with this in mind – for instance, Part 3 guidance includes proficiencies related to leadership and complex care coordination that would be inappropriate for a first-year student. Practice Assessors should ensure that by the end of Part 3, the student is functioning at the level of an entry- level registered nurse across all platforms of proficiency.

Annexe B Procedures and Field-Specific Application: The NMC’s Annexes to the Standards of Proficiency outline specific skills and procedures that all new nurses must be able to demonstrate. Annexe A covers communication and relationship management skills, and Annexe B covers a broad range of clinical nursing procedures. The procedures in Annexe B are divided into sections (often referred to as Part 1 and Part 2 of Annexe B). Importantly, Annexe B procedures are additional to the main proficiency statements – they support and underpin the proficiencies but are not proficiencies in themselves[8]. At the point of registration, an adult nurse must be able to safely demonstrate all the procedures listed in Annexe B, meaning give a practical demonstration or clearly explain how to perform them, providing evidence such as performing the skill in practice, simulation, or via discussion and reflection[9].

The NMC expects that Annexe B procedures be assessed in the student’s own field of practice whenever practicable[10]. “Practicable” means if it can be done in that context, it should be – acknowledging that opportunities will vary by placement[11]. For adult field students, most Annexe B skills (e.g. taking vital signs, wound care, medication administration) will naturally occur in adult care settings. Some procedures that are more common in other fields (e.g. care of a child or mental health specific interventions) are still required knowledge, but adult students would demonstrate them at an appropriate level for adult care[12][13]. Conversely, students from other fields might fulfill adult-oriented procedures through simulation or spoke placements. For example, an adult nursing student needs to understand mental health interventions (like de-escalation techniques or cognitive therapies) and may encounter these if an adult patient has those needs, but they are not expected to become expert mental health clinicians – just competent to recognize and support those needs or seek help appropriately[14]. Where a certain procedure is not available in the student’s placement (for instance, an adult student in general practice may not see chest drain management), the student can demonstrate it through simulation or during an alternative experience.

This toolkit links each proficiency to relevant Annexe B skills where applicable. By following the suggestions, students should inherently cover Annexe B requirements. For instance, a proficiency about maintaining a patient’s airway will naturally involve demonstrating or simulating airway management procedures (an Annexe B skill). It should be noted that some Annexe B procedures might only be achievable given the right circumstances. Not every placement will provide exposure to every procedure (for example, not all adult placements will have patients requiring NG tube insertion). In such cases, different assessment methods can be used to achieve these procedures, such as simulation, case studies, or spoke visits[11]. The toolkit encourages creative strategies – a list of which is provided in the next section – to ensure all procedures are eventually demonstrated by the completion of the programme. Suggestive Methods of Assessment

Proficiencies can be demonstrated and assessed in various ways. The following methods are commonly used, often in combination, to gather evidence that a student has achieved a given outcome. Deciding which method is appropriate depends on the nature of the skill or knowledge, as well as opportunities available in the placement. The student’s Practice Assessor will make the final assessment decision, informed by evidence from these methods.

Direct Observation: The student performs the skill or task in the practice setting while a registered practitioner observes. This is the most straightforward way to

assess many clinical skills. For example, a student’s hand hygiene technique or blood pressure measurement should be assessed by directly watching them do it[17]. Direct observation provides first-hand evidence and can be supplemented by questions to confirm understanding (the “underpinning knowledge”). A proficiency demonstrated via direct observation is considered achieved once the observer (e.g. a nurse) confirms the student performed it safely and effectively[18][19]. This method is ideal for technical and interpersonal skills.

Demonstration through Discussion: The student explains, describes or answers questions about how they would perform a skill or handle a scenario, drawing on knowledge and maybe past experiences. This method is useful when actual performance opportunities are limited or when probing the student’s depth of understanding. For instance, a student might discuss how they would recognise and respond to sepsis, referencing current guidelines, even if they haven’t encountered an septic patient yet. Through professional conversation, including reflective accounts or reference to research and local policy, the student can demonstrate their proficiency in a cognitive sense[20][21]. If using this method, the Practice Supervisor/Assessor should ensure the discussion is robust and scenario- based, and document that the student showed sufficient knowledge to meet the outcome.

Simulation: Simulation involves re-creating clinical scenarios in a controlled environment (or sometimes within the placement) so that the student can practice and be assessed without risk to real patients. This can range from high-fidelity simulations (using manikins or actors in a sim lab) to simple role-play or scenario- based drills. Simulation is recognised by the NMC as a valid way to achieve practice hours and proficiencies, provided it is structured and supervised appropriately[22]. An effective simulation allows for repetition, feedback, and reflection[23]. For proficiency sign-off, a registered practitioner would observe the student’s performance in simulation and assess it as if in real practice[24]. For example, if a placement never encountered a cardiac arrest, a simulation of CPR can be used to demonstrate that proficiency. Simulation is especially helpful for invasive procedures like cannulation or catheterisation if real opportunities are scarce – the student can show the steps on a manikin to an assessor. It’s also used for emergency scenarios, communication exercises (like breaking bad news with an actor), and other situations to build confidence. Documentation

Spoke Placement / Training Opportunity: A spoke is a short visit or placement in an area outside the student’s main “hub” placement, designed to give exposure to specific learning opportunities. Students might arrange a spoke of a day or a week with a relevant team to meet a particular outcome. For instance, if a student’s main placement is surgical ward but they need experience with community wound care, a spoke day with a wound clinic can provide that. Spoke placements are coordinated with the help of Practice Educators or facilitators and must have

appropriate supervision. Evidence from a spoke could be an observation by a practitioner in that area, or a feedback testimonial. Spokes are particularly useful for proficiencies that are difficult to achieve in the main placement due to limited exposure[25]. For example, “a mental health nursing student may arrange an ‘out of field’ spoke placement to participate in the care of a patient requiring urethral catheterisation”[26] – similarly, an adult field student could do a spoke in a neonatal unit to observe infant feeding techniques, or in a community setting to understand social care assessments. Spoke opportunities also include attending training sessions (e.g. a diabetes pump workshop or moving & handling training) and area-based learning like specialist nurse clinics. The evidence is often a signed observation or certificate of completion. This method broadens the student’s experience and fosters interdepartmental and interagency understanding.

Feedback (Service Users, Carers, Staff): Feedback is a valuable form of evidence for proficiencies related to communication, professionalism, and caring behaviors. It involves gathering input from those who have interacted with the student – this could be patients and their families, or other healthcare team members. For instance, a patient might provide feedback that a student communicated with empathy and kept them well-informed during their care, which could evidence a communication proficiency. Similarly, a physiotherapist might give feedback that a student proactively assisted in mobility sessions and followed guidance well, evidencing teamwork. Feedback should be documented (e.g. via feedback forms or testimonials) and can corroborate the student’s performance in less directly observable areas like compassion and advocacy[27][28]. While feedback alone may not confirm technical skill, it enriches the evidence, especially when combined with observation or discussion. Triangulating evidence – i.e., using feedback alongside the assessor’s own observations and the student’s reflection – provides a stronger, more holistic basis for assessment decisions.

These methods are not mutually exclusive. In fact, the strongest evidence often comes from a combination. For example, a student might directly observe a complex wound dressing in the morning, then later have a discussion with their supervisor to explain the rationale and what they learned, supplemented by a reflection they write and perhaps some feedback from the patient about their communication. All of this together demonstrates the proficiency comprehensively. Practice Assessors are encouraged to be flexible and use all available evidence when signing off proficiencies, in line with NMC guidance that assessment should be objective, evidence-based, and drawing on feedback from supervisors[29].

NMC Key Statements

Contemporary nursing practice and education in the UK are governed by several key NMC standards and guidelines. Below is a summary of the foundational documents and principles that inform this toolkit, providing context and rationale for the expectations placed on students and supervisors:

Future Nurse: Standards of Proficiency for Registered Nurses (NMC, 2018): This is the core document detailing what newly qualified registered nurses must know and be able to do. It is structured into seven platforms (domains) of proficiency – ranging from being an accountable professional to coordinating care – which apply across all fields of nursing[16][30]. The standards emphasize that registered nurses must provide coordinated, compassionate, evidence-based, person-centred care to people of all ages and in all settings[31]. They highlight the importance of nurses working autonomously and collaboratively within interdisciplinary teams[32]. The proficiencies are outcome-focused and designed to reflect modern healthcare needs, including areas like mental health, public health, and leadership in every nurse’s role. Notably, the 2018 standards require that students develop proficiency not only in their own field (e.g. Adult) but also an understanding of care across other fields – for example, adult nurses should be aware of mental health needs and vice versa[14]. The standards are accompanied by Annexe A and Annexe B which list specific communication skills and nursing procedures

example, adult nurses should be aware of mental health needs and vice versa[14]. The standards are accompanied by Annexe A and Annexe B which list specific communication skills and nursing procedures that underpin the broader outcomes[16]. Together, these standards set the benchmark for registration; this toolkit is organized around ensuring students meet these proficiencies in practice.

Annexe B – Nursing Procedures: Annexe B (part of the above standards) specifies a comprehensive list of clinical procedures that all registered nurses must be able to perform safely by entry to the register[33]. These include procedures for assessing, delivering and evaluating care – such as taking vital signs, administering injections, performing wound care, managing nutrition and hydration (including enteral feeding), urinary catheterisation, venepuncture, cannulation, managing IV infusions, blood transfusions, and more. The key principle is that these procedures must be demonstrated effectively and with compassion, reflecting evidence-based practice and an understanding of the person’s holistic needs (e.g., cultural considerations, communication during the procedure)[34]. The NMC clarifies that “at the point of registration, the nurse will be able to safely demonstrate the following procedures” – meaning students can be assessed on these in any appropriate setting (clinical or simulated) before qualifying[35]. Different fields of nursing will emphasize different procedures (for instance, mental health settings might not have many IV insertions), so the NMC allows flexibility: procedures should be assessed in the student’s own field where practicable, and if not, in an alternative context[10]. Standards for Student Supervision and Assessment (NMC, 2018): Often abbreviated as SSSA, these standards replaced the old mentorship standards and introduced the distinct roles of Practice Supervisor, Practice Assessor, and Academic Assessor. The SSSA outlines how students should be supported in

practice and how assessment decisions should be made. Practice Supervisors are registered professionals (nurses, midwives, nursing associates – and even other registered health and social care professionals) who facilitate learning and supervise students day-to-day[5][36]. All registered nurses can be supervisors – it’s a role that focuses on being a role model and providing feedback. Practice Assessors are registered nurses (for nursing students, they must be same field) who conduct assessments to confirm whether students have achieved proficiencies and outcomes[29]. A practice assessor is assigned to the student and, informed by supervisors’ input, makes objective decisions about student progression[37]. Academic Assessors (usually a university lecturer) work in partnership with the practice assessor to review the student’s overall progress and recommend progression to the next Part or to qualification[38]. at all times appropriate to their learning needs[39]; supervisors provide constructive feedback and serve as role models[40]; assessors conduct fair and evidence-based assessments, and there must be good communication between practice and academic assessors to triangulate student performance[41][42]. Additionally, SSSA requires that those in these roles are prepared and supported – e.g., new practice assessors should be orientated to their role. This toolkit’s guidance on supervision (section below) is grounded in these standards, ensuring that the processes of student support and assessment uphold NMC requirements.

The Code: Professional Standards of Practice and Behaviour for Nurses, Midwives and Nursing Associates (NMC, 2018): Commonly known as “the NMC Code,” this is an essential document that all registered nurses (and students, as nurses in training) must adhere to. It’s structured around four key principles: Prioritise People, Practise Effectively, Preserve Safety, and Promote Professionalism and Trust[43]. The Code underpins everything a nurse does. For example, prioritising people means putting the interests of those in your care first, treating them with kindness, respect and compassion, and upholding their dignity. Practising effectively involves delivering care based on the best evidence, communicating clearly, and working cooperatively with colleagues. Preserving safety means acting within your competence, preventing harm, and speaking up if safety is compromised. Promoting professionalism and trust covers behaving with integrity, upholding the reputation of the profession, and being accountable for your actions. Serious breaches of the Code (like poor attitude, dishonesty, or unsafe practice) would result in a student not achieving proficiencies regardless of technical skill. The Code is thus a constant point of reference – supervisors and assessors should coach students on Code principles and may use it as a framework when giving feedback (“e.g., how did the student prioritize the patient’s comfort?” or “did they speak up about a potential safety issue?”). Standards Framework for Nursing and Midwifery Education (NMC, 2018): This is a set of standards that all AEIs and their practice partners must meet in delivering NMC-approved education programmes. It ensures the programmes have effective governance, curricula, student support, and quality improvement processes. In practice terms, these standards guarantee things like: students will experience a learning culture that is safe, inclusive and supportive; there will be collaborative relationships between universities and placement providers; students’ competence is assessed fairly and validly; and educators are suitably qualified. For example, one theme in the framework is about the learning culture – it should empower students and ensure equality and diversity principles are upheld[44][45]. Another part of the framework stipulates that programmes must have robust procedures to address issues like poor performance or academic misconduct. While students and supervisors may not interact with the framework directly, it works behind the scenes to assure the quality of placement learning. By familiarizing themselves with these key NMC documents, students and practice staff can better understand why certain proficiencies and assessment processes are in place. The ultimate goal of all these standards is to ensure that upon registration, the nurse is safe, competent, and confident to deliver high-quality care. This toolkit translates those expectations into practical guidance for day-to-day learning in the clinical environment.

Guidance for Supervision of Student Nurses

High-quality supervision is critical in practice learning. The NMC’s Standards for student supervision and assessment (SSSA) set out clear roles and responsibilities to ensure students are supported and assessed fairly. Below is guidance on how Practice Supervisors, Practice Assessors, and Academic Assessors should collaborate, as well as expectations for documentation, coaching, managing concerns, and ensuring robust evidence for assessment:

Roles and Responsibilities: Every nursing student is supervised in practice by at least one Practice Supervisor (often many over time) and has a designated Practice Assessor for a given period (e.g., a placement or year), as well as an Academic Assessor for each part of the programme[48][38].

Practice Supervisor (PS): A Practice Supervisor is any registered professional (commonly a nurse, but can be midwife, nursing associate or other registered health/social care professional) who works with the student and supports their learning on a day-to-day basis. All registered nurses are capable of being practice supervisors – there is no longer a requirement for a specific mentorship qualification to supervise[5]. The PS role is to enable the student to learn while ensuring safe care. Supervisors serve as role models by demonstrating best practice in their clinical work[49][50]. They provide guidance, answer questions, allow the student to observe and then perform skills under appropriate oversight. A PS should tailor the level of supervision to the student’s competence and confidence: for a new student, this might mean direct close supervision; for a more experienced student, it could mean granting more autonomy but still checking in regularly[51][52]. Practice Supervisors are expected to give timely, constructive feedback to students about their progress toward proficiencies[53]. For example, a PS might debrief with the student after a wound dressing to discuss what went

expected to give timely, constructive feedback to students about their progress toward proficiencies[53]. For example, a PS might debrief with the student after a wound dressing to discuss what went well and what could be improved. They also liaise with the Practice Assessor, sharing observations and insights about the student. Importantly, any patient care performed by a student remains the responsibility of the supervisor overseeing them at that time; the student is not counted in staffing numbers. Supervisors should be familiar with the student’s learning objectives and the proficiencies they need, helping create learning opportunities (e.g., arranging for the student to accompany a specialist nurse if relevant). If a supervisor has any concerns about a student’s practice (e.g., unsafe technique or unprofessional behavior), they must address it immediately (to preserve safety) and inform the Practice Assessor so that appropriate support or action can be taken[54][55].

Practice Assessor (PA): A Practice Assessor is a registered nurse (for nursing students, specifically in the same field of practice, i.e. adult) who is responsible for assessing and signing off the student’s achievements in practice for a given part of the programme[56][49]. Each student is assigned a practice assessor – often this might be one of the nurses on their ward or placement who has taken on the assessor role and usually does not simultaneously supervise the student day-to- day (to maintain objectivity)[57]. The PA’s job is to periodically review the student’s progress (through midpoint and final interviews or assessments), consider feedback from various supervisors, and ultimately decide if the student has met the required proficiencies and outcomes for that placement or part[58][59]. Assessment decisions by practice assessors must be evidence-based and documented[58][60]. This means the PA should gather and consider multiple sources of evidence: their own observations of the student, feedback from practice supervisors or other colleagues, the student’s reflections, skills logs, and any patient feedback. Academic Assessor (AA): The Academic Assessor is typically a university faculty member (such as a nursing lecturer) who is assigned to the student for a part of the programme. Their role is to oversee the student’s academic progress and link this with practice progress. At designated points (often end-of-part boards or progression meetings), the academic assessor reviews the student’s academic work and the practice assessor’s recommendations, and then confirms that the student has met all requirements to move forward or graduate[38][63]. The AA and PA are expected to communicate in order to evaluate the whole picture of the student’s performance[64][65]. For example, if a student struggled in practice but excelled academically (or vice versa), the AA and PA would discuss to ensure consistency in judging competence. The Academic Assessor also provides academic support and can help interpret or advise on NMC standards, ensuring the practice assessment is in line with educational standards. Each part of the programme, a different AA is usually assigned (to maintain objectivity across progression points). Students should know who their academic assessor is and can approach them if any issues arise that straddle academic and practice aspects. For example, if a student had extenuating circumstances affecting both coursework and placement, the AA would coordinate with practice colleagues on how to manage this. In essence, the AA validates the practice assessment from the school’s side and contributes to decisions like whether a student needs a remedial placement or whether they can enter the final placement, etc., in line with program standards[48].

Supervision in Practice: From the first day in a placement, a student should be introduced to the team and have identified supervisors each shift (one of whom is their point of contact). The NMC requires that students are always supervised according to their learning needs – initially directly, and later maybe indirectly (where the supervisor is available but not physically with the student at every moment) as appropriate[51]. A good strategy is for the student and supervisor at the start of a shift to agree which activities the student will do independently, which with direct oversight, and which not at all if beyond scope. For example, a Year 3 student might administer oral medications under distant supervision (checked but not hovered over), whereas a Year 1 student would do it only by observing or with step-by-step guidance. Supervisors should use judgement: if the student is safe to attempt a skill, let them, but be ready to step in if needed. The goal is to gradually increase the student’s autonomy while ensuring patient safety. All supervision and teaching should be documented in the student’s log (many PADs have a section for “Learning summary” each day). If a student is not getting enough exposure to certain proficiencies due to the nature of the environment, supervisors and the student should flag this early to the Practice Assessor so alternate arrangements (like spokes or simulations) can be made.

Documentation Expectations: Practice Assessors are responsible for completing the official assessment documentation (such as the PAD or electronic equivalent like OnlinePARE) to record decisions on proficiency achievement. This documentation should be done accurately and in a timely manner[62]. Delaying documentation can jeopardize a student’s progression, since universities need the completed records to allow the student to move on. A recommended approach is for the PA to document midway feedback (mid-point interview form) and final decisions (final interview) with clear rationale, especially if any proficiency is marked 'No' or concerns exist. Any proficiency signed as achieved (Yes) should ideally have some evidence noted – for instance, “Achieved – observed managing 2 patients’ care over 2 weeks with positive feedback from staff”. PAs should also verify that all required fields are completed: attendance hours, patient feedback forms, reflective journals, etc., as per local assessment documents (like MORA, if midwifery; PAD for nursing, etc.). Handover between Assessors: If a student moves to a new placement or a new PA takes over, a handover of progress should occur[66]. The previous PA’s notes and any action plans should be communicated so the next PA is aware of ongoing goals or issues. This continuity helps avoid repeating interventions or missing ongoing concerns.

Coaching Approach: As mentioned in the User Guide, adopting a coaching model of supervision helps build students’ critical thinking and confidence. Practice Supervisors can use the “ask-tell” balance: ask the student first what they think or how they would proceed, then tell or guide as needed. Techniques like the OSCAR or GROW coaching models (Goal, Reality, Options, Will) can be used informally in practice – e.g., “What do you think is the priority for this patient right now?” (Goal), “What have you noticed about

their condition?” (Reality), “What could we do next?” (Options) and then “Okay, try doing X and I’ll support you” (Way forward). Such dialogue encourages active learning. Students often report that being allowed to try (within safe limits) and then getting constructive feedback is most beneficial. A coaching culture also means seeing mistakes or knowledge gaps as learning opportunities rather than simply failures. If a student does something incorrectly (but no harm done because supervisor was present), the supervisor can debrief: “Let’s talk through that – what went wrong and how to do it differently next time.” This approach, rather than scolding, maintains psychological safety for the student, which ironically encourages them to be more open about limitations and thus learn more. Practice Assessors can also coach in their periodic reviews, guiding the student to self- assess (“Which proficiencies are you most concerned about? How can we get you there?”) and helping them create their own action plans. Empowering students in this way aligns with the NMC’s push for autonomous, reflective practitioners.

Handling Concerns and Action Planning: If at any point a supervisor or assessor becomes concerned that a student is not meeting expectations or is unsafe, it is vital to address it early. Do not wait until the final week to raise issues. The first step is usually an informal conversation with the student to clarify expectations and hear their perspective – perhaps there are underlying issues (stress, personal difficulties, lack of knowledge) that can be solved. If the issue is minor (e.g., struggling with a skill), targeted support can be given. For more significant concerns (e.g., frequent medication errors or attitude problems), the Practice Assessor should be informed immediately. Together with the Academic Assessor or link tutor, they may decide to initiate a formal Action Plan or “learning contract.” This written plan will outline: the specific areas of concern, the improvement goals, actions the student must take, what support will be provided, and a timeline for review. For example, an action plan could state: “Proficiency: Administration of medications – Concern: Student has difficulty performing dosage calculations accurately. Action: Student to complete drug calculation

an action plan could state: “Proficiency: Administration of medications – Concern: Student has difficulty performing dosage calculations accurately. Action: Student to complete drug calculation e-learning module and have 3 supervised med rounds focusing on calculations. Support: Supervisor X will tutor on calculations 1:1. Review: check progress after one week, by [date].” Such plans should be agreed and signed by student and assessor, and a copy given to the Academic Assessor/AEI. If improvement is not seen by the review, the issue is escalated – possibly extending placement, involving a Practice Education Facilitator, or, if safety is at risk, temporarily withdrawing the student from practice for remediation. Throughout, documentation is crucial: keep records of meetings, action plans, and outcomes. This not only guides the student but also provides evidence in case a fail decision is challenged. It’s also important to note that if a student displays any behavior that breaches the Code (like dishonesty or misconduct), that should be escalated to academic leadership immediately, as it may require investigation per university fitness-to-practise procedures.

Triangulation of Evidence: Practice Assessors should use a holistic view when assessing a student – meaning not relying on one single incident or one person’s opinion. This “triangulation” involves collecting evidence from multiple sources to inform decisions[29]. For example, to assess professionalism, the PA might consider: attendance records, feedback from a staff nurse, and the student’s adherence to uniform policy and

documentation standards. For clinical skills, the PA could look at: direct observation (by themselves or a supervisor’s report), the student’s written reflection on that skill, and maybe a quiz or questions they answered on the underpinning knowledge. By gathering at least three points of evidence for each proficiency (where possible), the assessor can be confident in the reliability of the assessment. It also protects the integrity of the process – if a student disputes a decision, the PA can demonstrate it was based on well-rounded evidence, not personal bias. The SSSA explicitly states that practice assessors’ decisions should be informed by feedback from practice supervisors[29] and others, and that they should make objective, evidence-based judgments[58][60]. One practical tip is for Practice Assessors to keep a brief “assessment notes” diary during the placement: jot down any significant observations or feedback excerpts with dates. Then use these notes during the final interview to ensure all achievements and concerns are considered. Likewise, Academic Assessors contribute to triangulation by bringing in the academic perspective – e.g., if a student excelled in simulation

to ensure all achievements and concerns are considered. Likewise, Academic Assessors contribute to triangulation by bringing in the academic perspective – e.g., if a student excelled in simulation or lab exams, that might be taken into account if a certain skill wasn’t seen often in practice. Ultimately, the triangulated approach leads to fairer outcomes: students get credit for all the learning they have demonstrated, and any decision of not achieved will be well-substantiated by a pattern of evidence, not just a one- off instance.

In summary, effective supervision of student nurses is a team effort grounded in clear communication, ongoing support, and rigorous but fair assessment practices. Practice Supervisors and Assessors must work hand-in-hand (with input from Academic Assessors and others) to create an environment where students can thrive, and where any issues are promptly addressed. By following the guidance above – aligning with NMC standards – we help ensure that students become competent, confident professionals, and that patient safety and care quality are maintained throughout the learning process.

Utilising Spoke Opportunities

A spoke placement is a short-duration learning experience in an area related to or different from the student’s main (hub) placement. Spoke opportunities are invaluable for broadening a student’s exposure, allowing them to develop skills and insights that the current placement might not offer. They also foster inter-agency and inter-professional awareness, as students often engage with services outside the immediate clinical team. Here’s how to effectively utilize spoke placements:

What is a Spoke? In simple terms, a spoke placement is like a “field trip” or mini- placement. It can range from a few hours observing a specialist, to a couple of days or a week embedded in another team. The idea is that the student leaves their main placement temporarily to experience another setting that offers learning relevant to their proficiencies. Spokes are typically arranged when a particular proficiency is difficult to achieve in the current placement’s context[25]. For example, an adult nursing student on a general medical ward might arrange a spoke day in the wound care clinic to observe complex dressings, or with the diabetes specialist nurse to learn about insulin pump management, if those opportunities are rare on the ward.

Arranging Spoke Placements: Usually, the student should discuss potential spokes with their Practice Assessor or Supervisor early in the placement. Together, they identify learning needs that the main placement might not meet fully. The student (with support as needed) can then reach out to relevant departments or use established contacts (often via the Practice Education Facilitator or link tutor) to set up the spoke. It’s important to ensure the spoke area is expecting the student and that a supervisor there is identified to orient and supervise the student during the visit. The main placement’s management must also approve (so they know why the student is absent on those days). Many universities and trusts have guidelines for spokes – some require a short agreement form to be filled, noting the date, location, and objectives of the spoke. The student should be proactive but also realistic: a spoke should have a clear purpose, not just be time away.

Examples of Spoke Opportunities for Adult Nursing: Adult field students have a wide array of possibilities, such as: - Clinical Specialist Teams: e.g., a tissue viability nurse (wound/frailty team) to see advanced wound therapies, a stoma care nurse, a heart failure specialist nurse, or a falls prevention clinic. These experiences can enhance skills like assessment and care planning for specific conditions (like chronic wounds or fall risks). - Outpatient or Community Clinics: e.g., a wound clinic (as mentioned), dialysis unit, oncology day unit, or a GP surgery clinic (to see primary care management of adult conditions). A day in a chemotherapy suite could teach about patient education and monitoring during infusions; a day with district nurses could show holistic assessment in patients’ homes. - Allied Health Professional (AHP) Spokes: spending time with physiotherapists, occupational therapists, or dietitians. For instance, attending a frailty multidisciplinary team meeting or shadowing a physio in a rehab gym can help meet proficiencies around mobility, rehabilitation, and multi-agency working[67]. - Social Care or Third-Sector Services: e.g., an adult student might visit a

a physio in a rehab gym can help meet proficiencies around mobility, rehabilitation, and multi-agency working[67]. - Social Care or Third-Sector Services: e.g., an adult student might visit a social services team, a nursing home, or a charity organization (like Age UK day center) to understand broader aspects of care continuity, social prescribing, and community support. This builds awareness of how different organisations contribute to a patient’s wellbeing beyond the hospital. - Diverse Population Health Needs: e.g., a spoke with a Learning Disability liaison nurse to see how care is adapted for adults with learning disabilities, or with a Mental Health liaison team in the hospital (for an adult student to gain insight into mental health crises management in A&E or wards). Another example is joining a substance misuse service for a day to understand addiction issues in patients who might be on the student’s ward. - Acute Specialties: If on a general ward, a student might do a spoke in A&E (Accident & Emergency) to witness emergency care, or in ICU/HDU to see higher level care – useful for recognizing deterioration and complex monitoring. A short placement in a theatre or

spoke in A&E (Accident & Emergency) to witness emergency care, or in ICU/HDU to see higher level care – useful for recognizing deterioration and complex monitoring. A short placement in a theatre or endoscopy suite might also be possible, giving insight into the perioperative patient journey and sterile procedures.

The toolkit encourages these kinds of experiences because they help students meet competencies that require a wider lens. For instance, a proficiency about “working in partnership to ensure safe discharge across services” could be well evidenced by a student spending time with a discharge coordinator or attending a community follow-up visit[68][69].

Documenting and Assessing Spokes: When a student goes on a spoke, they should have specific objectives (ideally linked to proficiencies). They should inform their Practice Assessor what they intend to achieve. During the spoke, a supervising professional in that area can provide evidence – often a short written feedback or signing a section in the PAD that the student observed/participated in X and demonstrated Y. For example, in a spoke to a falls clinic, the physiotherapist might write, “Student attended falls assessment clinic; actively participated in assessing two patients, identified risk factors in environment and medications, and discussed care plans – showed good communication with older patients.” This evidence can then be used by the Practice Assessor to sign off relevant proficiencies (like risk assessment, multi-agency working, health promotion for falls prevention). The student should also reflect on the spoke experience in their portfolio or PAD, noting what they learned and linking it to their proficiencies.

Benefits of Spoke Placements: Spokes are beneficial in multiple ways: - They allow students to meet learning outcomes that might otherwise be unmet in their main placement, thus ensuring a well-rounded competence. “Spoke placements can be useful if there is limited exposure to a proficiency in a specific field of nursing”[70] – this flexibility helps students in all fields meet the universal standards. - They enhance understanding of the patient journey. For example, an adult ward student who visits a community mental health team gains appreciation for what happens after discharge for a patient with dual physical and mental health needs. - They promote inter-professional learning. Working with other professionals or teams on a spoke helps break silos. Students learn the roles of others, which fosters better teamwork. For instance, an adult nursing student who spends time with an occupational therapist will better understand how to plan safe discharges (like home adaptations needed), improving their collaboration back on the ward. - They encourage initiative and self-directed learning. Arranging and completing a spoke requires the student to be proactive, which is a professional

improving their collaboration back on the ward. - They encourage initiative and self-directed learning. Arranging and completing a spoke requires the student to be proactive, which is a professional behavior in itself. - From a service perspective, spoke students can sometimes bring fresh enthusiasm to teams and strengthen relationships between hospital and community services or across departments.

Inter-agency Awareness: Through spokes, students often interact with external agencies – such as social workers, community matrons, or charity support workers. This builds awareness of the wider health and social care network. It’s important that nurses know how to signpost patients to these services (like referring to a social prescribing service for loneliness, or contacting a cultural liaison/diversity team for specific patient needs). A student might do a spoke with a hospital palliative care team and learn how they coordinate with hospice services; or visit a housing support organization to see social determinants of health firsthand. All these experiences contribute to a nurse who can work effectively across organisational boundaries – a key aspect of modern healthcare.

In conclusion, spoke placements are a strategic tool to enrich practice learning. Students should be encouraged and supported to utilize spokes thoughtfully, targeting them to their learning needs. Practice Assessors and Supervisors play a role in facilitating this (through flexibility in scheduling and using their networks to help set up experiences). By leveraging

spokes, a student can demonstrate creativity and commitment in meeting their proficiencies – and ultimately become a more versatile and knowledgeable practitioner. Always remember to bring the learning back to the main placement: after a spoke, students should share with their supervisors what they learned, possibly even presenting to the team if appropriate, thereby benefitting others and reinforcing their own learning.

Myth Busters

There are many misconceptions (“myths”) about practice learning and assessment. This section addresses common myths and provides factual clarification, helping students and supervisors focus on what is truly required. Below are several myth vs. fact pairings to clear up confusion:

Myth: “Students must demonstrate every procedure and proficiency in an actual clinical setting – simulation doesn’t count.” Fact: Simulation does count as a legitimate way to learn and be assessed. The NMC explicitly supports the use of simulated practice learning to complement clinical placements[22]. Students are not expected to have a real patient for every single skill (especially if circumstances don’t allow); many skills can be safely learned and assessed in simulation labs or through drills. For instance, if a ward never has pediatric patients, an adult field student can still demonstrate pediatric BLS or airway management on a child manikin in a sim session. Assessors can sign off proficiencies based on simulation as long as a registered practitioner has overseen the student’s performance and is satisfied it meets the standard[24]. In fact, simulation is invaluable for high-risk but low-occurrence scenarios (cardiac arrest, severe anaphylaxis, etc.) – it ensures students get exposure and practice in those areas. The bottom line: Simulation is recognized and encouraged by the NMC as a means to achieve proficiencies, not a lesser alternative. Of course, if a real clinical

exposure and practice in those areas. The bottom line: Simulation is recognized and encouraged by the NMC as a means to achieve proficiencies, not a lesser alternative. Of course, if a real clinical opportunity arises, that’s great, but a well-run simulation can provide equally robust evidence of competence (plus the opportunity to repeat and refine skills).

Myth: “Only my Practice Assessor’s observations can be used as evidence; feedback from other staff or patients doesn’t matter.” Fact: All relevant feedback and observations can contribute to the assessment decision. In the modern model, assessment is a collaborative effort. Practice Assessors are expected to seek and consider input from Practice Supervisors and others who work with the student[71][29]. So, if a senior healthcare assistant or a physiotherapist or a patient has given feedback about the student’s performance, that is valid evidence. For example, a patient’s compliment about how well a student provided education on their condition can support the proficiency on health promotion communication. Similarly, if three different nurses report that the student handles infection control excellently, the Practice Assessor should weigh that heavily. The myth likely stems from older models where only “sign-off mentors” mattered – but now practice supervision is a team activity. A Practice Assessor

makes the final call, but that call should be based on triangulated evidence (multiple sources) not just their own direct witnessing[29]. Additionally, a Practice Supervisor who directly observes a skill can sign in the PAD or give a statement for the PA to use. So students should engage with the whole team and gather feedback proactively. It’s also acceptable for skills to be initially signed by supervisors (if the PAD allows) and then the PA verifies them. The fact is: evidence of proficiency can include written testimonies from other professionals, skills lab assessments, patient feedback forms, reflective accounts, and more – not just the PA’s personal observation. Using a breadth of evidence leads to a fairer and more comprehensive assessment.

Myth: “Every example action in the toolkit (or PAD) must be completed for the proficiency to be achieved.” Fact: Not at all – the example actions are illustrative suggestions, not a mandatory checklist[4]. This toolkit and most PAD documents list several possible ways or sub-tasks by which a proficiency might be demonstrated. These are meant to guide and inspire, not to be ticked off one by one. A student can meet the proficiency through one or two well-evidenced actions; they do not need to do all the things on the list. For instance, if the proficiency is “Nutrition and hydration: contributes to planning, delivering and monitoring,” example actions might include assessing BMI, educating a patient about diet, and documenting fluid balance. The student might end up doing a thorough nutritional assessment and setting up a feeding plan for one patient – if that clearly demonstrates competence, that’s sufficient even if they didn’t, say, attend a dietician meeting (another example that might have been listed). The NMC’s stance is outcome-focused, meaning it’s about whether the student can achieve the outcome, not whether they tick off tasks[22]. In fact, overly focusing on ticking

might have been listed). The NMC’s stance is outcome-focused, meaning it’s about whether the student can achieve the outcome, not whether they tick off tasks[22]. In fact, overly focusing on ticking checklists can detract from holistic learning. Practice Assessors should use professional judgment: one student may evidence a proficiency differently than another, and that’s fine. Quality of performance matters more than quantity of tasks. The toolkit’s repeated reminder is that examples are not exhaustive nor compulsory – they’re “suggestive actions, not limited to” the list given[72][73]. So, use them as a menu of options and ideas, and feel free to substitute alternatives that achieve the same end.

Myth: “Any RN can’t be a supervisor or assessor unless they’ve done a specific mentorship course.” Fact: Under current NMC standards, any registered nurse (or midwife/NA) can supervise students as part of their role, provided they are prepared and supported by their employer[5][50]. The old “mentor” qualification is no longer a regulatory requirement. Practice Assessors should be registered nurses with suitable experience in the student’s field, and while many will have mentorship training or similar, it’s not mandated by the NMC now – it’s up to employers to ensure assessors are prepared. So, a ward staff nurse who hasn’t been on a mentorship course can still supervise a student (and in fact is expected to, as part of collective

responsibility). They would not, however, be the Practice Assessor unless designated as such; PAs often are more senior or experienced staff who have had some preparation. But even that is flexible – a competent Band 5 RN could be a PA if supported. The myth sometimes causes staff to shy away from working with students – but in truth, every registered nurse has a role in student education, guided by the Code to support the next generation (section on promoting professionalism and trust). Another angle: some think only nurses can supervise – but actually other registered professionals can too, for relevant learning experiences (e.g., a student could be supervised by an occupational therapist during a mobility session)[74][75]. The key is that these supervisors communicate with the nurse team. In summary, while most organizations still offer mentorship or supervisor training (which is good practice), lack of a formal “mentor” title does not exclude a nurse from supervising or even assessing within the SSSA framework. What’s important is that assessors are allocated and supported, and all supervisors know how to give feedback and guidance.

Myth: “Proficiencies can only be signed off if directly observed in person by the assessor.” Fact: Proficiencies should be demonstrated, but the demonstration can be to any suitable registrant who can then inform the assessment. The Practice Assessor does not need to personally witness everything. If a competency was observed by a Practice Supervisor (or multiple supervisors) consistently, the PA can accept their documented observations as evidence[71]. For instance, a night-shift supervisor might observe the student handling an emergency and later relay that to the PA, who wasn’t present – the PA can then discuss it with the student and use it as evidence of, say, managing care under pressure. The PA might ask the supervisor to write a short note in the PAD or email for the record. Additionally, certain proficiencies might be demonstrated via simulation or discussion with the PA rather than live clinical action – that’s still valid. The NMC encourages assessors to gather a range of evidence (direct and indirect)[29]. Of course, where possible, direct observation is great. But in reality, given shift patterns and breadth of skills, a PA will often rely on records and feedback from

(direct and indirect)[29]. Of course, where possible, direct observation is great. But in reality, given shift patterns and breadth of skills, a PA will often rely on records and feedback from others. This is perfectly acceptable. It prevents the student from being penalized just because the “right” person didn’t see them do something. A well-rounded assessment might include: direct observation by PA for some things, observation by others for some, scenario discussions for others – collectively building the case. So, the fact is that assessment is a team sport and not limited to the PA’s own sight. As long as the evidence is documented and trusted, the PA can use it. (The one exception: any summative exams or specific sign-off tools might require presence, but those are separate from ongoing proficiencies.)

These myth busters should reassure students and practice staff and correct any erroneous practices. By dispelling myths, we ensure everyone approaches the practice learning process with accurate information and less anxiety. Remember, when in doubt, refer back

to NMC standards or ask an Academic Assessor for clarification – often the answer will be that there is more flexibility and support than the myth suggests.

Proficiency Clustering

In real nursing care, skills and competencies do not happen in isolation – a single patient care scenario will often involve multiple proficiencies at once. “Proficiency clustering” refers to recognizing that one learning event or assessment opportunity can provide evidence for several proficiencies simultaneously. This approach encourages holistic learning and reduces the need to artificially compartmentalize skills. It also mirrors true nursing practice, where you integrate various skills seamlessly to care for a patient.

Concept: Proficiencies are listed individually in the standards and PAD, but they are not stand-alone tasks. The NMC acknowledges that a nurse’s actions usually demonstrate a combination of knowledge and skills[76]. For example, consider something as routine as a medication round: the student isn’t just “administering medicine” (procedure) – they are also communicating with the patient (communication proficiency), performing an assessment (checking patient identity, allergies, understanding), applying pharmacology knowledge (knowledge proficiency), and documenting (record-keeping proficiency). If we artificially split those, we’d miss the bigger picture that the student can coordinate all those aspects in one go.

Assessment in Clusters: Practice Assessors and Supervisors should consider, when planning an assessment, how one situation can tick off multiple proficiencies. This is efficient and realistic. For instance, a student leading a patient discharge planning meeting could be evidencing communication skills, collaborative working, teaching the patient about medications, understanding of referrals, and documentation – all in that one activity[68][77]. Instead of needing five separate sign-offs, the assessor might observe that discharge process and then sign off five related proficiencies at once, with appropriate commentary.

Example – Nursing Discharge (Year 2): As given in the toolkit, a part 2 student taking part in a discharge of a complex patient demonstrates a range of proficiencies. During that discharge process, the student will support the patient in making informed choices (Proficiency P1)[78], apply principles of partnership working and respect capacity (P2)[79], provide clear explanations about the patient’s treatment and follow-up (P5, P22)[80][81], ensure documentation like the discharge letter and care plan is accurate (P7)[82], and coordinate with other services for continuity of care (P31)[83]. In doing so, they might also demonstrate leadership and confidence appropriate to a Year 2 level. Instead of viewing P1, P2, P5, P7, P22, P31 as separate unrelated checkboxes, the assessor clusters them around the “discharge” event. If the student performed well, evidence from that event (like the supervisor’s observation notes, the completed referral form they filled, feedback from the patient or social worker present) can satisfy all those proficiencies. This not only saves time but reinforces to the student how these skills interlink in practice.

Example – Wound Care (Year 3): Imagine a Year 3 student managing a patient with a complex surgical wound. In one afternoon, the student assesses the wound (showing proficiency in assessment and decision-making), performs a dressing change with sterile technique (showing procedural skill and infection control), educates the patient on wound care at home (health promotion and communication), and documents the wound progress (record-keeping). This single scenario can provide evidence for proficiencies in assessment, infection prevention, patient education, pain management, and documentation. The assessor could cluster these under “Managed complex wound care for Patient X” and sign off multiple items such as: "Demonstrates person-centred assessment and monitoring of wound healing," "Performs wound dressing using aseptic technique," "Provides effective education to patient and carer," "Evaluates and documents care outcomes." Each is a distinct proficiency, but all were met together.

Example – Breaking Bad News (Communication & Emotional Support): If a student is involved in (or simulates) a scenario of breaking bad news or discussing end-of-life care with a patient and family, it’s an opportunity to cluster proficiencies related to communication, ethical practice, and interprofessional support. In that one conversation, the student might demonstrate empathy, ability to adjust communication to the situation, understanding of safeguarding or supporting vulnerable people, and working alongside perhaps a doctor or specialist nurse. A single observed “difficult conversation” could thus address: communication skills, respecting dignity, recognizing one’s role in the team (knowing when to get senior help), and emotional support measures. Instead of seeing those as separate, the assessor can write up a holistic account. This aligns with practice because breaking bad news is not a single skill – it’s a combination of knowledge, attitude, communication technique, and teamwork.

Encouraging Students to Think Holistically: Students can also be coached to identify clusters. At the start of a placement, a useful exercise is to pick a common procedure or activity and map out which proficiencies might be evidenced through it. For example, “Mr. A’s morning care” – that could hit on communication (talking to him during personal care), infection control (washing hands, PPE), fundamental care (bathing, skin inspection), assessment (noticing a pressure sore risk, or checking vital signs), and documentation (charting intake/output, etc.). By seeing this, students realize they don’t need a separate event for each line in the PAD; they need to maximize each event. This not only reduces their anxiety about “so many things to do” but also reflects how they will actually practice as nurses – integrating tasks efficiently.

Documentation of Clustered Evidence: When writing in the PAD or assessment forms, Practice Assessors should reference the cluster scenario and list which proficiencies it covered. For instance: “Observed student lead a MDT discharge planning meeting for patient with stroke (14/11/25). During this, student demonstrated: P2 – partnership and shared decision making (involved patient and OT in plans); P5 – provided clear information about medications and used teach-back; P7 – documentation in discharge plan was thorough and e-mailed to community team; P31 – coordinated with social worker for safe transition. All achieved to the level required.” This single narrative ties them together.

Similarly, any reflections the student writes can be more holistic (“Reflecting on coordinating that discharge, I realized I used many skills: communication, teamwork, clinical knowledge about stroke, etc.”).

Benefits of Clustering: It prevents the fragmentation of nursing care into artificial bits. It reinforces to the student how knowledge, skills, and attitudes come together. It also prevents over-assessing the student – if one situation suffices, there’s no need to set up five separate assessments which can lead to assessment fatigue and redundant paperwork. Clustering is also protective in terms of validity: it shows the student can bring everything together in context, which is ultimately what matters for safe practice. A student might tick off a skill in isolation (like calculating a drug dose on paper, or doing a manual handling move in a class), but the true test is doing it amidst real care. Clustering captures that.

Using Clustering for Complex Care: In higher parts (Year 3), patients often have complex needs – multiple conditions or social factors. A scenario like coordinating a complex discharge or managing a deteriorating patient will inherently cover multiple proficiencies (from acute care skills to leadership). For example, a student managing a patient who suddenly becomes hypoxic will use assessment skills (recognize signs), communication (call the doctor, SBAR), technical skills (maybe administer oxygen, do an ECG), and teamwork (allocate someone to reassure family, someone to fetch emergency trolley). If they do this in simulation or real life, an assessor can cluster acute care proficiencies (like “recognize and respond to deterioration,” “effective communication under pressure,” “team leadership in emergency,” and “infection control during emergency interventions”). This paints a richer picture of the student’s readiness for registration than ticking each independently at different times.

In essence, proficiency clustering is about seeing the forest rather than just the trees. It encourages a focus on integrated practice. When planning assessments or writing up evidence, think in terms of patient stories or nursing scenarios and identify the constellation of competencies within them. As one nursing educator aptly said, “Nursing is not a checklist; it’s a tapestry of skills woven together.” Clustering helps us evaluate how well students can weave that tapestry. By using this approach, we also prepare students to think comprehensively – to always consider the whole patient and situation, rather than performing tasks in isolation. This ultimately leads to better, safer care and nurses who are reflective and versatile in their practice.

(For additional guidance, the NMC’s standards framework encourages integrative assessment approaches and many AEIs provide examples of how multiple outcomes can be met in a single assessment – leveraging that can simplify the journey for both student and assessor.)
